name: Cape Porcupine
description: Its body is covered with stiff hairs, quills, and spines. On its back, these form a mane that it raises when agitated. Some tail quills are hollow, producing a rattling sound when the animal shakes its tail in threat.
food_note: Underground plant parts, fallen fruits, bark
image_alt: Cape porcupine, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 53–83 cm; tail length 2–13 cm; weight 13–27 kg
reproduction: Gestation lasts 90–94 days; 1–3 young are born.
attractions: In this species, it’s the female that initiates mating by turning her back to the male, lifting her tail, and lowering her quills away from him when in heat. It lives solitarily or in family groups with offspring of varying ages. Newborns have open eyes, developed teeth, and soft quills that soon harden. Initially, they stay in a softly lined burrow bed. Porcupines dig burrows up to 20 meters long themselves, retreating to them for safety and rest, and often use natural rocky shelters.
breeding: A relatively new species here, the first arrived in 2003 and began breeding in 2004.
